data.passage:
In ice hockey, icing is when a player on one team shoots the puck all the way down the ice and it crosses the red line at the end of the rink, and is then touched by a member of the opposing team. When this happens, play is stopped and a face-off occurs in one of several places depending on where exactly on 
the rink surface
the puck was shot from. Icing can be used tactically as an energy conserving measure to keep opponents away from your goaltender or as part of defensive zone coverage; however it also carries some risk because if an opponent touches that puck before any other members of your own team do (even if they were behind him), he may shoot it into your unguarded net for what would otherwise be considered "an empty net goal". Play often continues even after apparent icing has occurred; officials will not stop play unless they are reasonably certain that no infraction has taken place. Players who touch or deflect pucks that might have been subject to icing are said to "wave off" icing.
data.question: Is shooting the puck across entire lengthof rink always called as 'icing'?

7.62×54mmR is a rimmed rifle cartridge developed by the Russian Empire and was introduced as a service round in 1891. Originally designed for black powder, it was adapted to smokeless powder and used both in original rifles and in machine guns (both are still referred to as 7.62×54mmR cartridges). It remained the standard Soviet infantry rifle cartridge until 1930 when it was replaced by the 7.62x39mm M1930 round which has similar ballistics but less recoil.[1] 
7.62×54mmR ammunition is manufactured worldwide today - including many "Western" countries - mainly due to large numbers of surplus Mosin-Nagant rifles available on global arms markets while factory loads tend towards full metal jacket bullets rather than more traditional military bullet designs such as those with exposed lead tips or copper jackets leaving only lead cores exposed at the base.[2][3]
